lines.text: The saddest thing in life is wasted talent.

[as C walks out of Sonny's funeral]
Sonny and my father always said that when I get older I would understand. Well, I finally did. I learned something from these two men. I learned to give love and get love unconditionally. You just have to accept people for what they are, and I learned the greatest gift of all. The saddest thing in life is wasted talent, and the choices that you make will shape your life forever. But you can ask anybody from my neighborhood, and they'll just tell you this is just another Bronx tale.
dump her.
Just like that?

Listen to me, kid. If she doesn't reach over and lift up that button so that you can get in, that means she's a selfish broad and all you're seeing is the tip of the iceberg. You dump her and you dump her fast.
Now yous can't leave.
What's your name, kid?
Calogero.
That's a long name. Don't you have a nickname?
No.
What do your friends call you?
Calogero.
That makes sense.

Mickey Mantle? Is that what you're upset about? Mickey Mantle makes $100,000 a year. How much does your father make? You don't know? Well, see if your father can't pay the rent go ask Mickey Mantle and see what he tells you. Mickey Mantle don't care about you, so why should you care about him? Nobody cares.

He's wrong, it don't take much strength to pull a trigger but try getting up every morning day after day and work for a living, let's see him try that, then we'll see who the real tough guy is, the working man is the tough guy, your father's the tough guy!
[after Sonny just allows unwanted bikers to drink in his bar]
You got some brews down here. Nice cold ones. Get us some nice cold brews, come on. Two over here, huh? One more here, one more.
[Sonny takes Calogero outside and talks to him]
Alright, brothers. If I may. A toast to our host.
[They all salute]

[as they shake their drinks and spray them all over the bar]
In the name of the father, the son and the holy ghost!
[Sonny gets angered by this and confronts them again]
Look at all the shit all over me.
[the bikers curse at him]
Hey!
Oh, you again.
That wasn't very nice. Now youse gotta leave.
I'll tell you when the fuck we leave alright. Get the fuck away from me.

[the bikers laugh at Sonny as he walks to the door]
Go watch the bikes eh!
[Sonny locks the front door. All the bikers look and curse at him]
Now youse can't leave.

[narrating]
"I will never forget the look on their faces. All eight of them. Their faces dropped. All their courage and strength was drained right from their bodies. They had reputation for breaking up bars, but they knew that instant, they'd made a fatal mistake. This time they walked into the wrong bar."
[a fight ensues between the bikers and Sonny's gang]

You gotta do what your heart tells you to do. Let me tell you somethin' right now. You're only allowed three great women in your lifetime. They come along like the great fighters, every ten years. Rocky Marciano. Sugar Ray Robinson. Joe Louis. Sometimes you get 'em all at once. Me? I had my three when I was 16. That happens. What are you gonna do? That's the way it goes, you know? Tell you right now. See this girl? Maybe this girl, she put wind in your sails. Maybe she's your first great one.
First of all, I respect you, Lorenzo, you're a stand-up guy and we're from the same neighbourhood, but don't ever talk to me like that again. I tell yor kid to go to school, to go to college...
it's not what you say, it's what he sees, the clothes, the cars, the money, it's everything. He tried to throw away his baseball cards because he said Mickey Mantle will never pay the rent.

[laughs]
He said that to you? I don't believe this kid.
[They all laugh]
That's not funny. Not when your kid has a bigger bank account than you.
I offered you a job, you said "No" to me.
That's right, and I say "No" now. Just leave my son alone, please.
Hey!
[Stands up]
Don't you see how I treat that kid? I treat him like he's my son.
He ain't your son, he's MY son.
He's what?
He's MY son!
Hey, get the fuck outta here!

[Shoved by the gangsters towards the door]
I'm not afraid of you.
You should be.

I know who you are, Sonny, I know what you're capable of, and I would never step out of line, you can ask anyone in the neighbourhood who knows me. But this time, you're wrong. You don't fool with a man's family. This is my son, not yours.
What are you gonna do, fight me?
You stay away from my son!
Get outta here before I give you a fucking slap!
You just stay away from my son!
Go ahead!
I don't care who you are! You stay away from my son!
[the gangsters force him out of the bar]
Don't be afraid, my son. No one is more powerful than God.
I don't know about that, father. Your guy may be bigger than my guy up there, but my guy is bigger than your guy down here.
Ya got a point.
Look at me! I did this to you! REMEMBER ME!
Sonny had five fingers, but he only used three.
It was 1960 and doo-wop was the sound on the street.
We've been mushed!
You borrow my car. And then you give her the test.
What? The Mario test?
Mario? Mario's a fucking psycho.
Sometimes in the heat of passion, the little head tells the big head what to do, and the big head should think twice about what you are doing.

[Coming to Calogero's defense against the angry gangsters]
Calogero! Calogero!
[to Sonny]
What happened to my son?
Drive your bus and get the fuck out of here!
I'll get my fucking bus!
[Tries to hit Sonny, but the gangsters grab him]
You put your hands on me, I'll stick you in the fucking ground!
[the gangsters punch Lorenzo in the stomach and knock him down]
Next time find out what's going on before you open your mouth.

[about C]
The other night he tried to throw away his baseball cards because he said Mickey Mantle would never pay our rent.

[laughs]
He said that to you? I can't believe that kid.
[They all start laughing]
That's not funny. Not when your kid has a bigger bank account than you do.
It was great to be Catholic and go to confession. You could start over every week.
[Anello family eats steak once a week]
I'm not in the mood for steak.

[looking at C's burned friends]
They started out as white bread now they toast.

[to C]
THEY LOOK BETTER NOW, DON'T THEY LOOK BETTER!
They say you didn't walk with JoJo, you walked among him.
I wanna shoot someone y'kno and this feels like just the gun to do it with.
You stay away from that bar. You don't see me going to the bar do you ?
You mean Mom wont let you go either?
What am I gonna do with this kid ?
[a biker gang called The Satan's Messengers enters Sonny's bar wearing their biker clothes]
Fellas, youse are not dressed properly. Youse gonna have to leave.
Properly? What's wrong with the way we're dressed?
Jimmy! What's up?
These gentleman ain't dressed right, and I asked them to leave.

[confronting them]
Is there a problem here?
Nah, the problem is your man here says we're not properly dressed. Like our money ain't green. We just want a couple of beers.
A few beers, that's it?
That's it. We'll be on our way. We ain't looking for trouble.
Spoken like a gentleman. Give em the beers. Go ahead.
Thanks, appreciate it.
[Sonny whispers to Jimmy to go in the back room and prepare the guys]

[to Calogero]
What is it, li'l white motherfucker?
No-no-no. Coffeecake, no good. I don't want that face lookin' at his face when he's rollin' my dice. Jimmy! Grab a towel from the bar!
Mommy! Mommy! Look what I got! Some peaches... for... free.
[he sees his parents about to confront him]

[showing C the wad of cash]
What's this?
What's what, Dad?
Where'd you get this? Your mother found it behind your drawer.
It's my savings, Dad.
600 dollars you've been saving? What'd you do, become a brain surgeon overnight, son?
Tell your father where you got the money!
I worked for it.
Doin' what?
Things.
Things? Whadaya mean 'things'? What things?
Things. Y'know, things.
Don't lie to me. Just tell the truth and I won't get upset.
Promise?
I'm your father. Would I say it if I didn't mean it?
I worked the crap games and the guys gave me tips.
Crap games?
Crap games? What crap games?
[C looks down]
What crap games? What tips?
[still no answer]
WHAT CRAP GAMES?
I thought you weren't gonna get upset, Dad.
I lied! Now tell me everything!
I told you. I worked for Sonny and the guys gave me tips.
I knew it!
Didn't we tell ya a thousand times not to go near that bar?
[a few blacks cross the road on bicycles]
What the fuck, man? What the fuck? These fuckin' spooks just came out of nowhere!
Why don't you just leave em alone?
What the fuck is it with you and these niggers lately?
They ain't bothering nobody.
They're FUCKIN' bothering me!
They ain't bothering me.
They started out as white BREAD. Now they're toast!
lift weights, play cards, or get in trouble.
What did you do?
Me, I read.

[hears knocking on the door]
Who is it?
POLICE. Is this the Anello residence?
Yeah, could I help ya?
Look, we're detectives. We'd like to ask you some questions.
About what?
Just open the door!

[walks into the Lorenzos']
I'm Detective Belsik.
[points to Vella]
This is my partner Detective Vella.

[to Calogero]
Hello, son.
[to Mrs. Anello]
How ya doin' ma'am?

[turns to Lorenzo]
We'd like to ask your son a few question.
About what?
There was a shooting in front of the building a little while ago and we believe your son was there.
Really? Well, he don't know nothin' about that.
Well, we feel he DOES. There were people who saw him.
Well, they're WRONG. He don't know nothin'.
Listen, Mr. Anello, we could do things the nice way or we could do things the hard way. Alright? We could go down to headquarters...
I don't care what way you do it! He don't know nothin'!
Daddy, I know everything.
Kids, ya know, sometimes they make believe they see things.
We didn't pick your name out of a hat. We know your son was down there. So, come on, let's go.

[to Calogero]
Son, listen. Here's what I'd like you to do for us. I'd like you to take a walk downstairs with us. And your father. We have some people down there. All I want you to do is pick out the person you saw with the gun in his hand. *That's* *it*. Do you think you could do that for us?

[thinks about it, looks at his father]
Yeah.

[after Calogero looks at a whole lineup and doesn't identify the shooter]
You satisfied, officer?
No, I'm not satisfied.
He don't know. He can't help you.

[cynically]
Yeah, yeah, I know. Your son doesn't know anything. I know all about it.
He said no. He can't help you.

[annoyed]
I'll tell ya what, take a walk. G'head. G'head.
